title: What is a condenser microphone? - Quora

response.answer_text: “Condenser” is an old term for “capacitor” — essentially two conductive plates parallel to one another but separated by an insulator such as plastic or air that are capable of holding a charge. In a condenser microphone, sound waves impinge on a charged flexible diaphragm that makes up half of the capacitor:  Since capacitance is a function of the distance between charged plates, the motion of the diaphragm relative to the fixed electrode behind it changes the capacitance and a current flows. This current is then amplified and becomes the audio signal. The main advantage of a condenser microphone is that because the diaphragm has a very low mass, it is much more accurate than a conventional dynamic microphone. For that reason, condenser microphones are generally preferred in applications where sound quality is important. The main disadvantage is that, unlike a dynamic microphone, a condenser microphone requires a power supply to charge the plates. Professional equipment often has an option to supply “phantom power” to a condenser microphone via the mic connectors. However, it is possible to make inexpensive electret microphones in which the diaphragm is permanently charged, obviating the need for a power supply in consumer applications.
